sutra:
ॐ पूर्णमदः पूर्णमिदं पूर्णात् पूर्णमुदच्यते।

पूर्णस्य पूर्णमादाय पूर्णमेवावशिष्यते॥

ॐ शान्तिः शान्तिः शान्तिः॥
transliteration_kn:
ಓಂ | ಪೂರ್ಣಮದಃ ಪೂರ್ಣಮಿದಂ ಪೂರ್ಣಾತ್ಪೂರ್ಣಮುದಚ್ಯತೇ ।
ಪೂರ್ಣಸ್ಯ ಪೂರ್ಣಮಾದಾಯ ಪೂರ್ಣಮೇವಾವಶಿಷ್ಯತೇ ॥

ಓಂ. ಶಾಂತಿ! ಶಾಂತಿ!! ಶಾಂತಿ!!!
transliteration_hi:
ॐ पूर्णमदः पूर्णमिदं पूर्णात् पूर्णमुदच्यते।

पूर्णस्य पूर्णमादाय पूर्णमेवावशिष्यते॥

ॐ शान्तिः शान्तिः शान्तिः॥
transliteration_en:
oṃ pūrṇamadaḥ pūrṇamidaṃ pūrṇātpūrṇamudacyate |

pūrṇasya pūrṇamādāya pūrṇamevāvaśiṣyate ||

oṃ śāntiḥ | śāntiḥ | śāntiḥ ||
meaning_en: That is complete; this is complete. From completeness emerges completeness. When completeness is taken from completeness, completeness still remains.
meaning_kn: ಅದು ಪೂರ್ಣವಾಗಿರುತ್ತದೆ, ಇದು ಪೂರ್ಣವಾಗಿರುತ್ತದೆ. ಪೂರ್ಣದಿಂದ ಪೂರ್ಣವು ಉದ್ಭವಿಸುತ್ತದೆ. ಪೂರ್ಣದಿಂದ ಪೂರ್ಣವನ್ನು ತೆಗೆದುಹಾಕಿದರೂ, ಉಳಿದುದೂ ಪೂರ್ಣವಾಗಿರುತ್ತದೆ. ಓಂ ಶಾಂತಿಃ ಶಾಂತಿಃ ಶಾಂತಿಃ॥
tellmemore_en_adv: This mantra reinforces the teachings of Advaita Vedanta by illustrating the infinite nature of both the supreme, unmanifested Brahman and the manifested, conditioned Brahman. It teaches that the universe, with all its diverse forms, emerges from the infinite Brahman, retaining its inherent infinitude. Through the knowledge of this true nature, one realizes that the conditioned Brahman (the manifested world) is essentially the same as the supreme Brahman. This realization dissolves the illusion of separateness, revealing the underlying unity of all existence. By understanding the infinite nature of both the source and the manifestation, one attains the vision of oneness, which is central to Advaita philosophy. The repeated invocation of peace signifies the ultimate tranquility and liberation that come with this profound realization.
tellmemore_en_dva: In Dvaita philosophy, which maintains a dualistic understanding of reality, this mantra underscores the distinct and complete nature of both the Supreme Being (Vishnu or Brahman) and the individual souls (jivas). According to Dvaita, "That" (Adah) refers to the Supreme Brahman, who is perfect and complete in itself. "This" (Idam) refers to the individual soul, which is also complete in its essence. The mantra illustrates that the Supreme Brahman is the source of all creation and remains unchanged and complete even after the creation process. The individual soul, though a part of creation, retains its distinct completeness derived from the Supreme. Despite the infinite process of creation, Brahman’s infinitude remains undiminished, highlighting the eternal, unchanging nature of God. The invocation of peace (Shanti) three times at the end signifies peace in the physical, mental, and spiritual realms, acknowledging the overarching completeness and tranquility of the divine.
tellmemore_en_vis:
The mantra "Om Purnamadah Purnamidam" emphasizes the completeness and fullness of both the ultimate reality (Brahman) and the manifested world. According to Vishishtadvaita, Brahman, with its infinite attributes and auspicious qualities, pervades everything, and this world is a manifestation of Brahman’s glory.

"That (other world) is full with the Veda" signifies that the spiritual realm is complete and perfect, filled with divine knowledge and truth as embodied in the Vedas. "This (world) is full with the Veda" implies that even the physical world is permeated with the divine knowledge and presence of Brahman.

The phrase "That which fills is more celebrated than the world that is filled" highlights the supremacy of Brahman, the source of all creation and existence. The manifested world, though full and complete in itself, derives its completeness from Brahman.

When the "Vyahrithi," or the agent of filling, is withdrawn from the world, what remains is the "Om Karatmaka Vastu," the ultimate reality characterized by Om, which is Brahman. This signifies the inherent and unchanging nature of Brahman, even when the dynamic aspects of creation and sustenance are set aside.

In essence, this mantra encapsulates the belief that Brahman is both immanent and transcendent, pervading all of existence while remaining beyond it. This fullness is the ultimate reality that remains constant, highlighting the non-dual yet multifaceted nature of Brahman as understood in Vishishtadvaita.

sutra:
केनेषितं पतति प्रेषितं मनः। केन प्राणः प्रथमः प्रैति युक्तः।
केनेषितां वाचमिमां वदन्ति। चक्षुः श्रोत्रं क उ देवो युनक्ति ॥ ||१||
transliteration_kn:
ಕೇನೇಷಿತಂ ಪತತಿ ಪ್ರೇಷಿತಂ ಮನಃ। ಕೇನ ಪ್ರಾಣಃ ಪ್ರಥಮಃ ಪ್ರೈತಿ ಯುಕ್ತಃ।
ಕೇನೇಷಿತಾಂ ವಾಚಮಿಮಾಂ ವದನ್ತಿ। ಚಕ್ಷುಃ ಶ್ರೋತ್ರಂ ಕ ಉ ದೇವೋ ಯುನಕ್ತಿ ॥ ||೧||
transliteration_hi:
केनेषितं पतति प्रेषितं मनः। केन प्राणः प्रथमः प्रैति युक्तः।
केनेषितां वाचमिमां वदन्ति। चक्षुः श्रोत्रं क उ देवो युनक्ति ॥ ||१||
transliteration_en:
keneṣitaṃ patati preṣitaṃ manaḥ। kena prāṇaḥ prathamaḥ praiti yuktaḥ।
keneṣitāṃ vācamimāṃ vadanti। cakṣuḥ śrotraṃ ka u devo yunakti ॥ ||1||
meaning_en:
Whoever sent the mind sent falls. By what is the life-force first reached?
Who sent this word? Who is the god who unites the eyes and the ears?
meaning_hi:
जिसने भी मन भेजा वह गिर गया। जीवन-शक्ति तक सर्वप्रथम किससे पहुंचा जाता है?
यह संदेश किसने भेजा? वह कौन सा ईश्वर है जो आँखों और कानों को जोड़ता है?
meaning_kn:
ಮನಸ್ಸನ್ನು ಕಳುಹಿಸಿದವನು ಬೀಳುತ್ತಾನೆ. ಜೀವಶಕ್ತಿ ಮೊದಲು ಯಾವುದರಿಂದ ತಲುಪಲ್ಪಡುತ್ತದೆ?
ಈ ಪದವನ್ನು ಯಾರು ಕಳುಹಿಸಿದ್ದಾರೆ? ಕಣ್ಣು ಮತ್ತು ಕಿವಿಗಳನ್ನು ಒಂದುಗೂಡಿಸುವ ದೇವರು ಯಾರು? ||೧||

sutra:
श्रोत्रस्य श्रोत्रं मनसो मनो यत्। वाचो ह वाचं स उ प्राणस्य प्राणः।
चक्षुषश्चक्षुरतिमुच्य धीराः। प्रेत्यास्माल्लोकादमृता भवन्ति ॥ ||२||
transliteration_kn:
ಶ್ರೋತ್ರಸ್ಯ ಶ್ರೋತ್ರಂ ಮನಸೋ ಮನೋ ಯತ್। ವಾಚೋ ಹ ವಾಚಂ ಸ ಉ ಪ್ರಾಣಸ್ಯ ಪ್ರಾಣಃ।
ಚಕ್ಷುಷಶ್ಚಕ್ಷುರತಿಮುಚ್ಯ ಧೀರಾಃ। ಪ್ರೇತ್ಯಾಸ್ಮಾಲ್ಲೋಕಾದಮೃತಾ ಭವನ್ತಿ ॥ ||೨||
transliteration_hi:
श्रोत्रस्य श्रोत्रं मनसो मनो यत्। वाचो ह वाचं स उ प्राणस्य प्राणः।
चक्षुषश्चक्षुरतिमुच्य धीराः। प्रेत्यास्माल्लोकादमृता भवन्ति ॥ ||२||
transliteration_en:
śrotrasya śrotraṃ manaso mano yat। vāco ha vācaṃ sa u prāṇasya prāṇaḥ।
cakṣuṣaścakṣuratimucya dhīrāḥ। pretyāsmāllokādamṛtā bhavanti ॥ ||2||
meaning_en:
The ear of the ear is the mind of the mind. The word is the word, and he is the life-force of the life-force.
They are patient, opening their eyes to their eyes. They are immortalized from this world after death.
meaning_hi:
कान का कान मन का मन है। शब्द तो शब्द है, और वह जीवन-शक्ति की भी जीवन-शक्ति है।
वे धैर्यवान हैं, अपनी आँखें खोलकर खड़े हैं। वे मृत्यु के बाद इस संसार से अमर हो जाते हैं।
meaning_kn:
ಕಿವಿಯ ಕಿವಿಯೇ ಮನಸ್ಸಿನ ಮನಸ್ಸು. ಪದವೇ ಪದ, ಮತ್ತು ಅವನು ಜೀವಶಕ್ತಿಯ ಜೀವ ಶಕ್ತಿ.
ಅವರು ತಾಳ್ಮೆಯಿಂದಿರುತ್ತಾರೆ, ಅವರ ಕಣ್ಣುಗಳಿಗೆ ಕಣ್ಣು ತೆರೆಯುತ್ತಾರೆ. ಅವರು ಮರಣಾನಂತರ ಈ ಲೋಕದಿಂದ ಅಮರರಾಗುತ್ತಾರೆ. ||೨||
tellmemore_en_adv:
This entire universe, including everything that moves and everything that doesn't, is covered by the Divine. Understanding this Divine presence is important because it is our true nature. To live a peaceful and content life, we need to let go of our attachment to material possessions and desires. The core principle of Advaita philosophy is realizing that "I am the inner Self of all beings."

This realization removes the illusion of separateness and brings a sense of unity with everything. Wealth and material possessions are not truly owned by anyone because everything is part of the Divine. Therefore, we should live contentedly, recognizing the unity of all existence.

By giving up the desire for wealth and embracing the idea that everything is a part of the Divine, we can lead a life of peace and spiritual growth. This understanding opens the path to spiritual development and brings us eternal happiness and peace.
tellmemore_en_dva:
God is present everywhere, and everything in the universe depends on Him. God is the one who makes everything function, and without Him, nothing can exist or work. He is the only independent entity, while everything else, including the material world and living beings, rely on Him.

For spiritual growth, it is crucial to eliminate greed. Since everything we have is given by God, we should be content with what He provides. Greed and the desire for more are futile because all things and beings are under God's control. Realizing God's omnipresence and His role as the sustainer of the universe helps us reduce our greed and live a life of contentment.

This understanding leads to recognizing the unity of all existence and our dependence on the Divine. By accepting that everything belongs to God, we can focus on spiritual growth and inner peace.
tellmemore_en_vis:
God, specifically Sriman Narayana, pervades everything in the universe. This includes both living (sentient) and non-living (insentient) entities. God is distinct from these entities but exists within them as their innermost self. Without God's presence and guidance, nothing can function. He alone is truly independent, and all other things depend on Him.

The term "vasyam" signifies that God dwells in everything, everywhere, as the inner self. This verse teaches us to enjoy life with a sense of detachment and without greed. Greed is unnecessary because all entities and their functions are under God's control. The mantra advises us to use only what is necessary for living and spiritual practice, without any attachment. By recognizing God's omnipresence and our dependence on Him, we can live a life free from the desire for wealth and material possessions, focusing instead on spiritual growth.
tellmemore_kn_adv:
ಈ ಇಡೀ ಜಗತ್ತು, (ಚಲಿಸುವ ಮತ್ತು ಸ್ಥಿರವಾಗಿರುವ ಎರಡೂ), ದೈವದಿಂದ ಆವೃತವಾಗಿದೆ. ದೈವಿಯ ತತ್ತ್ವವನ್ನು ಅರಿತುಕೊಳ್ಳುವುದು ಮುಖ್ಯ, ಏಕೆಂದರೆ ಇದು ನಮ್ಮ ನಿಜ ಸ್ವರೂಪವಾಗಿದೆ. ತ್ಯಾಗ ಮತ್ತು ತೃಪ್ತಿಯಿಂದ ಬದುಕಲು, ಪ್ರಪಂಚದ ಭೌತಿಕ ಆಸೆಗಳನ್ನು ಮತ್ತು ಬಾಂಧವ್ಯವನ್ನು ತ್ಯಜಿಸಬೇಕು. "ನಾನು ಎಲ್ಲಾ ಜೀವಿಗಳ ಆಂತರಿಕ ಆತ್ಮ" ಎಂಬ ಸತ್ಯವನ್ನು ಅರಿತುಕೊಳ್ಳುವುದು ಅದ್ವೈತ ತತ್ವದ ಮುಖ್ಯ ಅಂಶವಾಗಿದೆ. 

ಈ ಜ್ಞಾನವು ನಮ್ಮಲ್ಲಿ ವಿಭಿನ್ನತೆಯ ಭ್ರಮೆಯನ್ನು ಕಳೆದುಹಾಕುತ್ತದೆ ಮತ್ತು ಏಕತೆಯ ಭಾವವನ್ನು ನೀಡುತ್ತದೆ. ಸಂಪತ್ತು ಮತ್ತು ಭೌತಿಕ ಆಸ್ತಿಗಳು ಯಾರಿಗೂ ಸ್ವಂತದ್ದಾಗಿಲ್ಲ, ಏಕೆಂದರೆ ಎಲ್ಲವೂ ದೈವದ ತತ್ತ್ವದ ಪ್ರದರ್ಶನ ಎಂದರೆ ತಪ್ಪಾಗದು. ಹೀಗಾಗಿ, ನಮ್ಮ ಆಂತರಿಕ ಆತ್ಮವನ್ನು ಅರಿತುಕೊಂಡು, ತೃಪ್ತಿಯ ಜೀವನವನ್ನು ನಡೆಸಬೇಕು. 

ಸಂಪತ್ತಿನ ಆಸೆಯನ್ನು ಬಿಟ್ಟು, ದೈವದ ಭಾಗವೆಂದು ಎಲ್ಲಾ ಅಸ್ತಿತ್ವವನ್ನು ಒಪ್ಪಿಕೊಂಡು, ಪ್ರಪಂಚದ ಎಲ್ಲ ಜೀವಿಗಳೊಂದಿಗೆ ಏಕತೆಯ ಭಾವವನ್ನು ಇಟ್ಟುಕೊಂಡು, ಶಾಂತಿಯುತ ಜೀವನವನ್ನು ನಡೆಸಲು ನಾವು ಪ್ರಯತ್ನಿಸಬೇಕು. 

ಈ ತತ್ತ್ವಜ್ಞಾನವು ನಮ್ಮಲ್ಲಿ ಆಧ್ಯಾತ್ಮಿಕ ಬೆಳವಣಿಗೆಯ ಮಾರ್ಗವನ್ನು ತೆರೆದು, ನಮಗೆ ಶಾಶ್ವತ ಸಂತೋಷ ಮತ್ತು ಸಮಾಧಾನವನ್ನು ತಂದುಕೊಡುತ್ತದೆ.
tellmemore_kn_dva:
ದೇವರು ಎಲ್ಲೆಡೆ ಇದ್ದಾನೆ ಮತ್ತು ಎಲ್ಲವೂ ಅವನ ಮೇಲೆಯೇ ಅವಲಂಬಿತವಾಗಿದೆ ಎನ್ನುವುದನ್ನು ಈ ಮಂತ್ರವು ಸೂಚಿಸುತ್ತದೆ. ದೇವರಿಲ್ಲದೆ ಯಾವುದೂ ಅಸ್ತಿತ್ವದಲ್ಲಿರುವುದಿಲ್ಲ ಅಥವಾ ಕಾರ್ಯನಿರ್ವಹಿಸುವುದಿಲ್ಲ. ಅವನು ಮಾತ್ರ ಸ್ವತಂತ್ರನು, ಇತರ ಎಲ್ಲಾ ವಸ್ತುಗಳು ಮತ್ತು ಜೀವಿಗಳು ಅವನ ಮೇಲೆಯೇ ಅವಲಂಬಿತವಾಗಿವೆ.

ಆಧ್ಯಾತ್ಮಿಕ ಬೆಳವಣಿಗೆಗೆ, ಲೋಭವನ್ನು ತೊಡೆದುಹಾಕುವುದು ಅತ್ಯಂತ ಮುಖ್ಯ. ನಮ್ಮಲ್ಲಿರುವ ಎಲ್ಲವನ್ನೂ ದೇವರು ನೀಡಿದ್ದು, ಅವನು ಕೊಟ್ಟದ್ದರಲ್ಲಿ ತೃಪ್ತವಾಗಿರಬೇಕು. ಹೆಚ್ಚು ಬೇಕೆಂಬ ಆಸೆ ಮತ್ತು ಲೋಭ ನೆರವಾಗುವುದಿಲ್ಲ ಏಕೆಂದರೆ ಎಲ್ಲಾ ವಸ್ತುಗಳು ಮತ್ತು ಜೀವಿಗಳು ದೇವರ ನಿಯಂತ್ರಣದಲ್ಲಿವೆ. ದೇವರ ಎಲ್ಲೆಡೆ ಇರುವಿಕೆಯನ್ನು ಮತ್ತು ವಿಶ್ವದ ನಿರ್ವಹಣೆಯಲ್ಲಿ ಅವನ ಪಾತ್ರವನ್ನು ಅರಿತುಕೊಳ್ಳುವುದರಿಂದ ನಾವು ಲೋಭವನ್ನು ಕಡಿಮೆಮಾಡಬಹುದು ಮತ್ತು ತೃಪ್ತಿಯ ಜೀವನವನ್ನು ನಡೆಸಬಹುದು.

ಈ ತತ್ತ್ವಜ್ಞಾನವು ಎಲ್ಲಾ ಅಸ್ತಿತ್ವದ ಏಕತೆಯನ್ನು ಮತ್ತು ದೈವದ ಮೇಲಿನ ನಮ್ಮ ಅವಲಂಬನೆಯನ್ನು ಅರಿಯಲು ಸಹಾಯ ಮಾಡುತ್ತದೆ. ಎಲ್ಲವೂ ದೇವರ ಆಸ್ತಿಯೆಂದು ಒಪ್ಪಿಕೊಂಡು, ನಾವು ಆಧ್ಯಾತ್ಮಿಕ ಬೆಳವಣಿಗೆಯ ಮೇಲೆ ಮತ್ತು ಆಂತರಿಕ ಶಾಂತಿಯಲ್ಲಿ ಕೇಂದ್ರೀಕೃತವಾಗಬಹುದು.

This verse from the Ishavasya Upanishad tells us that if a person wishes to live a long life, they should keep doing their duties and actions (karma) as prescribed by the scriptures. According to Shankara's commentary, this means following rituals and moral duties that are part of one's life. By doing so, a person can live up to a hundred years without being negatively affected by their actions. In simpler terms, it emphasizes the importance of doing good and righteous deeds throughout one’s life to avoid being trapped by the consequences of bad actions. This path is recommended for those who are not yet ready to renounce worldly life and seek knowledge of the Self (as mentioned in the previous verse).

Shankara also points out that there are two paths: one of action (karma) and one of renunciation (knowledge of the Self). For those who cannot renounce the world, performing their duties diligently is the way to live a fulfilling and unbound life.
tellmemore_en_dva: In Dvaita philosophy, the verse emphasizes the importance of performing one's duties with dedication to God. It suggests that one should aspire to live a long life, fulfilling their responsibilities as an act of worship. When duties are performed with devotion and without selfish motives, these actions do not bind the individual in the cycle of karma. Instead, they purify the mind and prepare the person for the knowledge of God. Failure to perform these prescribed duties, on the other hand, leads to sin and hinders spiritual progress. This is especially true for those who have not yet attained enlightenment, as neglecting duties can obstruct their path to liberation. Even for those who have gained knowledge and liberation, not performing duties like worship can reduce the bliss and fulfillment they experience. Thus, the verse highlights that dedicated action, done in the spirit of worship, is crucial for both spiritual progress and maintaining a pure, unattached mind.
tellmemore_en_vis: This verse emphasizes the importance of Nishkama Karma, which refers to actions performed without desire for personal gain, as essential for spiritual progress. According to Vishishtadvaita philosophy, one should desire to live a hundred years by performing their prescribed duties as an offering to God. Such selfless actions do not bind the individual because they are done with a sense of devotion and surrender to God. For someone who seeks Brahma Vidya, or knowledge of Brahman, performing duties without attachment ensures that karma does not taint them. Even if actions are done unintentionally, they do not cling to the person who has developed detachment and dedicated all actions to God. This approach helps in purifying the mind and preparing it for the realization of God. By remembering that all actions belong to God, one can transcend the cycle of birth and death and achieve liberation. The Bhagavad Gita also supports this doctrine of Karmayoga, emphasizing the importance of performing one's duties while remaining unattached to the fruits of actions.

ಆಳುವದರಿಂದ (ಇವನಿಗೆ) ಈಶ (ಎಂದು ಹೆಸರು) ಆ ಈಶನಿಂದ. ಆಳುವವನೆಂದರೆ (ಇಲ್ಲಿ) ಪರಮೇಶ್ವರನು: ಎಲ್ಲರ ಪರಮಾತ್ಮನು. ಏಕೆಂದರೆ ಆತನೇ ಪ್ರತ್ಯಗಾತ್ಮರೂಪದಿಂದ ಎಲ್ಲಾ ಪ್ರಾಣಿಗಳ ಆತ್ಮನಾಗಿದ್ದುಕೊಂಡು ಎಲ್ಲವನ್ನೂ ಆಳುತ್ತಿರುವನು. ಆ ತನ್ನ ಸ್ವರೂಪವಾದ ಆತ್ಮನೆಂಬ ಈಶನಿಂದ ಮುಚ್ಚಬೇಕು, ಹೊದಿಸಬೇಕು. ಏನನ್ನು? ಇದೆಲ್ಲವನ್ನೂ, ಈ ಜಗತ್ತಿನಲ್ಲಿ ಅಂದರೆ ಪೃಥ್ವಿಯಲ್ಲಿ ಏನೇನು ಯಾವಯಾವದು ಸ್ಥಾವರಜಂಗಮಾತ್ಮಕವಾದದ್ದು (ಇದೆಯೋ) ಅದೆಲ್ಲವನ್ನೂ ಪ್ರತ್ಯಗಾತ್ಮರೂಪದಿಂದ ಈಶನಾಗಿರುವ ತನ್ನ ಆತ್ಮನಿಂದ ’ಇದೆಲ್ಲವೂ ನಾನೇ’ ಎಂದು ಪರಮಾರ್ಥಸತ್ಯವಾಗಿರುವ ರೂಪದ ಪರಮಾತ್ಮನಿಂದ ಸುಳ್ಳಾಗಿರುವ ಈ ಚರಾಚರೆವೆಲ್ಲವನ್ನೂ ಹೊದಿಸಬೇಕು. ಹೇಗೆ ಚಂದನ, ಅಗಿಲು ಇವುಗಳಿಗೆ ನೀರೇ ಮುಂತಾದದ್ದರಿಂದಾದ ಉಪಾಧಿಯಿಂದುಂಟಾದ ಕೆಟ್ಟ ನಾತವು ಅವುಗಳನ್ನು ತೇಯುವುದರಿಂದ (ಹುಟ್ಟುವ) ತಮ್ಮ ನಿಜವಾದ ವಾಸನೆಯಿಂದ ಮುಚ್ಚಿಹೋಗುವದೋ ಅದರಂತೆಯೇ ತನ್ನ ಆತ್ಮನಲ್ಲಿ ಅಧ್ಯಸ್ತವಾಗಿರುವ ಸ್ವಾಭಾವಿಕವಾದ ಕರ್ತೃತ್ವಭೋಕ್ತೃತ್ವ ಮುಂತಾದ ರೂಪದ ದ್ವೈತರೂಪವಾದ ಜಗತ್ತು – ಜತ್ತಿನಲ್ಲಿ ಅಂದರೆ ಪೃಥ್ವಿಯಲ್ಲಿ; ಜಗತ್ತಿನಲ್ಲಿ ಎಂಬುದನ್ನು ಉಪಲಕ್ಷಣಕ್ಕಾಗಿ (ಉಪಯೋಗಿಸಿರುವುದರಿಂದ) ನಾಮ, ರೂಪ, ಕರ್ಮ – ಎಂಬ ಹೆಸರಿನ ಕಾರ್ಯ ಸಮೂಹವೆಲ್ಲವೂ ಪರಮಾರ್ಥಸತ್ಯವಾಗಿರುವ ಆತ್ಮಭಾವನೆಯಿಂದ ಬಿಟ್ಟು ಹೋಗುವುದು. 
ಹೀಗೆ ಈಶ್ವರಾತ್ಮನೇ ನಾನೆಂಬ ಭಾವನೆಯಿಂದ ಕೂಡಿರುವಾತನು ಪುತ್ರನೇ ಮುಂತಾದ ಏಷಣಾತ್ರಯವನ್ನು  ಬಿಡುವುದಕ್ಕೆ ತಕ್ಕವನೇ ಹೊರತು ಕರ್ಮಗಳಿಗೆ (ತಕ್ಕವ)ನಲ್ಲ. 
ಆದ್ದರಿಂದ, ತ್ಯಕ್ತದಿಂದ ಎಂದರೆ ತ್ಯಾಗದಿಂದ ಎಂದರ್ಥ: (ಬಿಡಲ್ಪಟ್ಟ ಎಂದರ್ಥವಲ್ಲ). ಏಕೆಂದರೆ ಬಿಡಲ್ಪಟ್ಟ ಸತ್ತುಹೋದ ಮಗನಾಗಲಿ ಆಳಾಗಲಿ ತನಗೆ ಸಂಬಂಧವಿಲ್ಲದವನಾದ್ದರಿಂದ ತನ್ನನ್ನು ಕಾಪಾಡಲಾರನು. ಆದ್ದರಿಂದ ತ್ಯಾಗದಿಂದ ಎಂಬುದೇ (ಸರಿಯಾದ) ಅರ್ಥವು. (ತ್ಯಾಗದಿಂದ ನಿನ್ನನ್ನು) ’ಭುಞ್ಜೀಥಾಃ’ ಕಾಪಾಡಿಕೊ. 
ಹೀಗೆ ಬಯಕೆಗಳನ್ನು ಬಿಟ್ಟ ನೀನು ಬಯಸಬೇಡ: ಬಯಕೆಯನ್ನು ಅಂದರೆ ಧನವಿಷಯದ ಆಸೆಯನ್ನು ಮಾಡಬೇಡ. ಯಾರ ಧನವನ್ನೂ-ಮತ್ತೊಬ್ಬನ ಅಥವಾ ನಿನ್ನ ಧನವನ್ನು – ಬಯಸದಿರು ಎಂದರ್ಥ. (ಕಸ್ಯಸ್ವಿತ್) ಎಂಬಲ್ಲಿ ಸ್ವಿತ್ ಎಂಬ ನಿಪಾತಕ್ಕೆ ಯಾವ ಅರ್ಥವೂ ಇಲ್ಲ. ಅಥವಾ (ಈ ವಾಕ್ಯಕ್ಕೆ ಮತ್ತೊಂದು ರೀತಿಯಲ್ಲಿ ಅರ್ಥವನ್ನು ಮಾಡಬಹುದು). ಬಯಸಬೇಡ: ಏಕೆಂದರೆ ಹಣವು ಯಾರದ್ದು? ಎಂದು (ಕಸ್ಯಸ್ವಿತ್ ಎಂಬ ಮಾತನ್ನು) ಆಕ್ಷೇಪಾರ್ಥ (ದಲ್ಲಿ ತೆಗೆದುಕೊಳ್ಳಬೇಕು). ಬಯಸುವುದಕ್ಕೆ ಯಾರ ಹಣವೂ ಇರುವುದಿಲ್ಲ. ’ಇದೆಲ್ಲವೂ ಆತ್ಮನೇ’ ಎಂದು ಈಶ್ವರಭಾವನೆಯಿಂದ ಎಲ್ಲವನ್ನೂ ಬಿಟ್ಟಿದ್ದಾಯಿತು. ಆದ್ದರಿಂದ ಇದೆಲ್ಲವೂ ಆತ್ಮನದೇ. ಇದೆಲ್ಲವೂ ಆತ್ಮನೇ. ಆದ್ದರಿಂದ ಸುಳ್ಳಾದ ವಿಷಯದಲ್ಲಿ ಬಯಕೆಯನ್ನು ಮಾಡಬೇಡ ಎಂದರ್ಥ. 
ಹೀಗೆ ಆತ್ಮನನ್ನು ಅರಿತಿರುವವನು ಪುತ್ರನೇ ಮುಂತಾದ ಏಷಣಾತ್ರಯವನ್ನು ಬಿಟ್ಟು ಆತ್ಮಜ್ಞಾನನಿಷ್ಠನಾಗಿ ತನ್ನನ್ನು ತಾನು ಕಾಪಾಡಿಕೊಳ್ಲಬೆಕೆಂಬುದು (ಮೊದಲನೆಯ) ವೇದವಾಕ್ಯದ ಅರ್ಥವು. ಇನ್ನು ಆನಾತ್ಮಜ್ಞರಾಗಿ ಆತ್ಮನನ್ನು ಅರಿತುಕೊಳ್ಳುವುದಕ್ಕೆ ಶಕ್ತಿಯಿಲ್ಲದ ಮಿಕ್ಕವರಿಗೆ (ಈ ಎರಡನೆಯ) ಮಂತ್ರವು ಇದನ್ನು ಉಪದೇಶಮಾಡುತ್ತದೆ.

tellmemore_en_adv: This verse from the Ishavasya Upanishad describes the fate of those who live in ignorance. It talks about dark realms known as 'asurya' which are completely covered in darkness. This darkness represents ignorance and a lack of spiritual knowledge. According to Shankara, people who do not recognize their true self and live without seeking higher knowledge are considered to be killing their own spiritual potential. These individuals, after their death, go to these dark and ignorant realms. The verse highlights the importance of seeking knowledge and understanding one's true nature to avoid such a fate. Living a life focused only on material pursuits and ignoring the spiritual aspect leads to a state of perpetual ignorance and suffering, both in this life and beyond. Therefore, the Upanishad urges people to seek enlightenment and realize their true self to avoid falling into these realms of darkness.
tellmemore_en_dva: In Dvaita philosophy, this verse warns about the severe consequences of acquiring and holding onto erroneous knowledge about God. It states that individuals who misunderstand or misrepresent the nature of God will face dire repercussions after death, being consigned to realms of deep darkness and suffering. These realms are described as hellish worlds, inhabited by demons and filled with immense misery. Before providing the correct understanding of God in the following verses, this verse underscores the importance of having accurate knowledge. Erroneous knowledge can manifest in two ways: either by denying the existence of God or by worshipping Him incorrectly based on false beliefs about His nature. Both forms of wrong knowledge are metaphorically equated to killing God because they distort the truth and lead one away from the path of righteousness. Such mistaken beliefs result in spiritual downfall and prevent one from attaining liberation. Therefore, the verse highlights the necessity of seeking true knowledge and understanding of God to avoid the disastrous consequences of ignorance and misbelief.
tellmemore_en_vis: This verse conveys a warning about the consequences of neglecting the knowledge of Brahman. It states that those who do not seek or gain knowledge of Brahman in this life are destined to go to the worlds enveloped in blinding darkness, known as asuric worlds, after death. These frightening realms, often described as naraka (hell), are where individuals with asuric (demonic) nature end up. The term "आत्महन्" is used metaphorically to describe people who, by ignoring the pursuit of knowledge about Brahman, lead themselves towards spiritual degradation and near non-existence. Such ignorance and neglect result in great sins, causing the self to deteriorate. In Vishishtadvaita, this emphasizes the urgency and importance of acquiring true knowledge and understanding of the Supreme Brahman to avoid such dire consequences and attain liberation.

tellmemore_en_adv:
This verse describes the true nature of the Self (Atman). It explains that the Self is steady and unchanging, yet it is faster than the mind. The senses, like sight and hearing, cannot catch up to it because it is always ahead of them. Even though it doesn't move, it surpasses everything else that moves. This is because the Self is present everywhere and in everything.

Shankara clarifies that the Self doesn't change or move, but it seems to be everywhere because it reflects in everything we perceive. The mind is considered the fastest because it can think of distant places instantly. However, the Self is already there even before the mind can think of it.

The verse also mentions Matariśva, which means the Mukya-Prana, symbolizing the vital force that sustains life. This force, guided by the Self, supports all activities in the universe. The Self remains constant and eternal, making everything else function.

In simpler terms, the Self is the ultimate reality that is constant and everywhere. It moves faster than the mind because it is beyond physical movement. The senses can't perceive it directly because it is beyond them. This Self supports all life and activities in the universe.
tellmemore_en_dva:
In Dvaita philosophy, this verse describes the nature of the Supreme God, emphasizing His immanence and transcendence. It highlights several key attributes of God. First, God is unmoved and fearless, indicating His supreme stability and absence of fear. He is also described as one, the ultimate and supreme being. Although deities and other beings cannot fully grasp or comprehend Him due to His infinite nature, He knows all from the beginning of time.

God is faster than the mind, suggesting His omnipresence and omniscience, able to surpass all thoughts and actions. Despite others running fast, He effortlessly overtakes them, symbolizing His supreme power and presence everywhere.

Mukhya-prana, the chief vital force, plays a crucial role by offering the deeds of all beings to God. This signifies that all actions performed by individuals are ultimately dedicated to and evaluated by God. It highlights the concept that humans are instruments of God, and their actions are a form of worship and devotion aimed at obtaining God's grace.

Understanding these characteristics helps devotees realize that God is the true doer, and by dedicating their actions to Him, they align themselves with divine will and purpose. This realization constitutes the essence of "samarpana" or offering at the feet of God, acknowledging His supreme authority and seeking His blessings.
tellmemore_en_vis:
This sloka highlights the unique and extraordinary nature of Paramatman (Supreme Self) in Vishishtadvaita philosophy. Paramatman is described as "Anejat," meaning unmoving, yet swifter than the mind. This paradoxical nature signifies that while Paramatman is changeless and steady, He transcends the speed and capabilities of the mind. 

The "Devas" or gods, representing various divine forces, cannot fully comprehend Him despite their swift nature because their knowledge is obstructed by Karma. The term "Ayeti Tishthat" suggests that Paramatman, residing as the inner self of all, remains stationary yet overtakes all entities that move. This implies His omnipresence and omnipotence, overseeing and regulating all activities in the universe.

Moreover, "Matarishva" (the Mukya Prana) symbolically carries out its duties by the will of Paramatman, indicating that even natural forces operate under His command. The verse thus underscores the supreme and all-encompassing power of God, who is both immanent and transcendent, providing the foundation and support for all existence. This realization leads to a deeper understanding of the divine presence within and outside, encouraging devotees to seek His grace and guidance.

tellmemore_en_adv: In Advaita philosophy, this verse emphasizes the unique and all-encompassing nature of the Self (Atman). The Self is unmoving and constant, yet it appears to move because it is present in all moving entities. It seems far away to those who are ignorant of its true nature, but it is very near to those who realize it, as it is their innermost essence. The Self is inside everything, being the core of all beings and objects. At the same time, it is outside everything, pervading the entire universe like space. This illustrates the non-dualistic view of Advaita, where the Self is the singular, all-pervasive reality that transcends and includes all existence. It unites everything in a continuous, unbroken presence, highlighting the oneness of all life and existence.
tellmemore_en_dva:
In Dvaita philosophy, this verse emphasizes the omnipresence and omnipotence of God. It conveys that God is the supreme authority whom everything in existence respects and fears. This is because all beings are dependent on Him, while He is independent and fears none.

The verse further describes God's omnipresence by stating that He is both near and far. This means that God is close to us, within our hearts, and also far-reaching, extending beyond the physical universe. His presence is not limited by space or distance, making Him simultaneously accessible and transcendent.

Additionally, God is described as being inside and outside all. He resides within every being, regulating and guiding their actions. At the same time, He exists outside, supporting and sustaining the entire creation. This dual aspect highlights His role as the inner controller and the external sustainer of the universe.

These descriptions illustrate God's infinite nature through paradoxes, showing that He encompasses all opposites and transcends all limitations. His presence and power are absolute, making Him the ultimate source of fear, respect, and reverence.
tellmemore_en_vis:
The verse describes the enigmatic nature of the Supreme Being, portraying it as both dynamic and static, distant and proximate, internal and external. In Vishishtadvaita philosophy, this signifies God's omnipresence and transcendence.

For those ignorant and attached to sensory pleasures, God seems distant, highlighting their spiritual separation from the divine. Conversely, to the devoted who focus their minds on Govinda (Vishnu) and renounce worldly desires, God appears near, illustrating the intimacy and accessibility of the divine through devotion and detachment.

This verse underscores that God pervades all existence, being both immanent within creation and transcendent beyond it. It emphasizes that the perception of God's proximity is determined by one's spiritual awareness and devotion. By recognizing this dual nature, believers are encouraged to seek a deeper connection with the divine, understanding that God is always present, both within and beyond the visible world. This recognition leads to a profound spiritual realization that transcends ordinary perception, inviting a closer, more personal relationship with the divine essence that permeates everything.
tellmemore_hi_adv: जिसका प्रकरण है वह आत्मतत्त्व एजन करता — चलता है, वही स्वयं नहीं भी चलता, अर्थात् स्वयं अचल रहकर ही चलता हुआ-सा जान पड़ता है। यही नहीं, वह दूर भी है; अज्ञानियोंको सैकड़ों करोड़ वर्षोंमें भी अप्राप्य होनेके कारण दूर- जैसा है । [ ' तद्वन्तिके' का ] तत् उ अन्ति- के ऐसा पदच्छेद करना चाहिये । वही अन्तिक - अत्यन्त समीप भी है अर्थात् केवल दूर ही नहीं, विद्वानोंका आत्मा होनेके कारण समीप भी है । वह इस सबके अन्तर यानी भीतर भी है, जैसा कि "जो आत्मा सर्वान्तर हैं" इत्यादि श्रुतिसे सिद्ध होता है । आकाशके समान व्यापक होनेके कारण वह इस नामरूप और क्रियात्मक सम्पूर्ण जगत् के बाहर तथा सूक्ष्मरूप होनेसे इसके भीतर भी है। और श्रुतिके "प्रज्ञानघन ही है" इस कथन के अनुसार वह निरन्तर ( बाहर- भीतरके भेदको त्यागकर सर्वत्र ) ही है ॥ ५ ॥

tellmemore_en_adv: In Advaita philosophy, this verse emphasizes the unity of all existence. It states that one who perceives all beings as manifestations within the Self, and recognizes the Self in all beings, transcends hatred and aversion. This perception comes from understanding that the Self (Atman) is the singular reality underlying all forms of life. When one realizes that every being is not separate but part of the same universal Self, feelings of division and enmity dissolve. This realization leads to a state of pure love and compassion, as there is no 'other' to dislike or hate. Seeing the Self in everything and everything in the Self is the essence of Advaita, promoting a vision of oneness and interconnectedness of all life.
tellmemore_en_dva:
In Dvaita philosophy, this verse emphasizes the unique relationship between God and all beings. It explains that all sentient beings exist within God, and God is present within all of them. This means that God is the ultimate support and regulator of everything in existence.

God being the abode of all implies that He is the foundation and the sustaining force behind all creation. Every being depends on Him for their existence and functioning. At the same time, God's presence within all beings indicates His role as an inner regulator, guiding and controlling their actions from within.

This understanding of God's omnipresence and omnipotence removes all fears, as recognizing His protective and guiding presence brings a sense of security and peace. Since God is all-powerful and independent, He has no need to protect Himself and is free from fear.

The verse also clarifies that there is no identity or sameness between the individual self and God. The relationship is one of dependence and regulation, not of oneness or merger. The use of the locative case indicates a clear distinction between God and the individual beings.
tellmemore_en_vis:
The verse offers profound insight into the nature of realization and unity in Vishishtadvaita philosophy. It suggests that a person who truly sees all beings within the Supreme Self and the Supreme Self within all beings transcends any form of aversion or contempt. This vision is not a superficial understanding but a deep, continuous contemplation that all entities, from the highest deity to the smallest living being, reside within Paramatman, the Supreme Soul.

Such a person perceives that the Supreme Soul is the inner essence of all beings, supporting and sustaining them. This realization brings about a profound change in perspective, where one no longer sees distinctions and separations but rather an underlying unity. The Supreme Soul is recognized as the true Self of all, permeating and existing within everything. This understanding eliminates any feelings of hatred or aversion, as one realizes that harming another is essentially harming oneself.

The verse emphasizes the importance of perceiving this unity, which leads to universal love and compassion. It signifies that the realization of the omnipresence of the Supreme Soul in all beings and all beings within the Supreme Soul is the foundation for ethical and harmonious living. This deeper understanding fosters a sense of oneness and respect for all life forms, highlighting the core principle of Vishishtadvaita that the Supreme Being, though distinct, is intimately connected with all aspects of the universe.

tellmemore_en_adv: In Advaita philosophy, this verse emphasizes the ultimate realization of oneness. It states that for a person who truly understands that all beings are manifestations of the Self, there is no room for delusion or sorrow. This realization comes from seeing the unity of all existence in the Self (Atman). When one perceives that everything is interconnected and that there is no true separation between beings, the causes of sorrow and confusion disappear. This state of awareness eliminates the ignorance that leads to feelings of isolation and suffering. The seer of oneness understands that all forms of life are essentially the same pure consciousness, leading to a state of eternal peace and bliss. In Advaita, this recognition of the non-dual nature of reality is the key to transcending all mental afflictions and achieving liberation.
tellmemore_en_dva:
In Dvaita philosophy, this verse reiterates the fundamental understanding that God is the ultimate support and regulator of all beings. All creatures find their foundation and sustenance in God, and He is present within each one of them, guiding and controlling their actions.

A person who truly understands that God is both the support and the inner regulator of all beings, and perceives the unity of God's presence in everyone, will be free from misconceptions and sorrow. This deep knowledge dispels erroneous beliefs and the grief that comes from such misunderstandings. Recognizing God's omnipresence and His role as the sustainer and regulator provides a sense of peace and clarity.

The verse emphasizes that there is no claim of identity between the individual self and all other beings. Instead, it highlights the distinction while acknowledging God's pervasive presence. By seeing God in all, a person transcends wrong knowledge and sorrow, attaining a state of true understanding and inner peace.
tellmemore_en_vis:
This verse emphasizes the state of realization where one perceives the Supreme Self as the essence within all beings. For a person who has attained this knowledge and sees all entities as manifestations of the Supreme Self, the concepts of delusion and sorrow become irrelevant. This realization comes from deep meditation and understanding the inherent unity in diversity.

The term "vijanatah" refers to one who has discerned the difference between the Independent Reality (Paramatman) and dependent entities (jivatman) as taught in the scriptures. Such a person sees Paramatman alone as characterized by all, rejecting theories of sublation, secondary application, or identity in nature.

This verse aims to affirm that Brahman is the self of all and that true knowledge dispels all delusions and sorrows by realizing that everything belongs to and is pervaded by Paramatman. This profound understanding leads to a state where no external loss, such as the death of a loved one or the loss of a kingdom, can cause grief, as everything is seen as part of the divine essence.

tellmemore_en_adv:
This verse describes the Self (Atman) as an entity that permeates everything in existence. It is entirely pure and without any physical form or body, meaning it doesn't suffer from wounds or have physical structures like sinews. The Self is immaculate and untouched by any form of sin or impurity. It possesses complete and infinite knowledge, understanding all things. Additionally, it is the master and guide of the mind, directing all mental processes. The Self transcends all physical and mental limitations, existing beyond the constraints of the material world. It exists independently, not relying on anything else for its being.

The verse also indicates that the Self has a role in organizing and maintaining the universe by assigning duties and functions to various entities and forces, ensuring the smooth and orderly operation of everything. This portrays the Self as the ultimate, unchanging reality that underlies and supports all existence, embodying the core principles of Advaita philosophy, which emphasize the unity and oneness of all life.

Thus, this verse reveals the Self as the pure, all-knowing, and ever-present essence that governs and transcends the universe, encouraging a deeper understanding of the interconnected and eternal nature of all existence.
tellmemore_en_dva:
In Dvaita philosophy, this verse highlights the attributes of God and their significance for the knower. God is described as being beyond sorrow, without a subtle body (linga sarira) or gross body, free from any limitations of time or attributes, and the embodiment of all purity. God is also unaffected by any sin, making Him the perfect being.

Understanding and realizing these attributes of God helps the devotee overcome false knowledge and sorrow. By knowing God in this way, one can see the true nature of existence and find peace.

The verse also emphasizes that God, who is omniscient and the lord of all minds, controls everything independently and has created the world truly throughout the ages. This underscores the reality of the world, countering the idea that the world is merely an illusion. Instead, it affirms that God has genuinely created the world with purpose and meaning.

The adjectives used to describe God convey His perfection and transcendence. God's lack of a subtle or gross body means He is not bound by physical limitations, yet He possesses a unique, divine form that allows Him to create and sustain the universe effortlessly.

Thus, this verse in Dvaita philosophy explains that knowing the true attributes of God—His purity, perfection, and independence—leads to liberation from false knowledge and sorrow. It affirms the reality of the world as a true creation of the divine, highlighting the importance of understanding God's true nature.
tellmemore_en_vis: This verse describes the Supreme Brahman as pure and self-luminous, free from bodily imperfections or sins, and self-existent. It highlights Brahman as the seer, knower, and controller, possessing complete wisdom and insight. Brahman is free from the limitations of a physical body, symbolizing purity and transcendence over material impurities. This Supreme Entity understands the true nature of all things and governs them eternally. The verse can also be interpreted to signify that a realized soul, or Sadhaka, who attains such knowledge of Brahman, embodies these divine qualities, achieving supreme purity and eternal wisdom through disciplined practice and devotion. This interpretation underscores the essence of Vishishtadvaita, which emphasizes the unity of the individual soul with Brahman, while still maintaining their distinct identities.
